headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Torchmark's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mike Majors, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. During the call today are Gary Coleman and Larry Hutchison, our Co-Chief Executive Officers; Frank Svoboda, our Chief Financial Officer; and Brian Mitchell, our General Counsel.Some of our comments or answers to your q
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. During the call today are Gary Coleman and Larry Hutchison, our Co-Chief Executive Officers; Frank Svoboda, our Chief Financial Officer; and Brian Mitchell, our General Counsel.
Some of our comments or answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements that are provided for general guidance purposes only. Accordingly, please refer to our 2014 10-K and any subsequent Forms 10-Q on file with the SEC. I will now turn the call over to Gary Coleman.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. In the fourth quarter, net operating income from all operations was $131 million or $1.05 per share, a per share increase of 5% from a year ago. During the fourth quarter, management determined that the Part D
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. In the fourth quarter, net operating income from all operations was $131 million or $1.05 per share, a per share increase of 5% from a year ago. During the fourth quarter, management determined that the Part D business met the criteria to be held for sale and has classified it as discontinued operations. Net operating income from continuing operations, which excludes Part D, was $131 million or $1.05 per share, up 6% on a per share basis from a year ago. Net income for the quarter was $133 million or $1.07 per share, a 5% decline on a per-share basis. The decline was due primarily to the fact that we had $11 million of tax-driven realized losses in the fourth quarter of this year compared to a gain of $5 million in the year-ago quarter.
With fixed maturities that amortized cost, our return on equity at December 31 was 14.5% and our book value per share was $30.09, an 8% increase from a year ago. 
On a GAAP reported basis, with fixed maturities and market value, book value per share was $32.71, a decline of 10% from a year ago. 
In our life insurance operations, premium revenue grew 5.5% to $521 million while life underwriting margins was $145 million, up 6.3% from a year ago. Net life sales increased 2% to $99 million. 
On the health side, premium revenue grew 5% to $235 million and health underwriting margin was up $51 million, approximately the same as a year ago. Health sales declined 17% to $60 million due to declining group sales. Individual health sales were $38 million, up 20%. 
Administrative expenses were $48 million for the quarter, up 9% from a year ago and in line with our expectations. As a percentage of premium from continuing operations, administrative expenses were 6.3% compared to 6.1% a year ago. The primary reasons for the increase in administrative expenses are higher information technology and pension costs. 
For the full year, administrative expenses were $186 million or 6.2% of premium. In 2016, we expect administrative expenses to grow approximately 5% and to remain around 6.2% of premium.
I will now turn the call over to Larry Hutchison for his comments on the marketing operations.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary. I will now go over the results for each company.At American Income, life premiums were up 8% to $213 million, and life underwriting margin was up 10% to $69 million. Net life sales were $50 million, up 9%, due primarily to increased age
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary. I will now go over the results for each company.
At American Income, life premiums were up 8% to $213 million, and life underwriting margin was up 10% to $69 million. Net life sales were $50 million, up 9%, due primarily to increased agent productivity. 
The average agent count for the fourth quarter was 6,590, up 4% over a year ago and approximately the same as the third quarter. The producing agent count at the end of the fourth quarter were 6,552. We expect the producing agent count to be in the range of 6,600 to 6,800 at the end of 2016. Life sales for the full year 2015 grew 15%. We expect 5% to 7% life sales growth in 2016.
In our Direct Response operation at Global Life, like premiums were up 7%, $185 million. Life underwriting margin declined 2% to $37 million. Net life sales were down 3% to $37 million. Life sales for the full year of 2015 grew 4%. We expect life sales to be flat or down slightly in 2016. 
At Liberty National, life premiums were $67 million, approximately the same as the year-ago quarter. Life underwriting margin was $19 million, up 24%. Net life sales decreased 5% to $9 million. Net health sales decreased 4% to $5 million. The average producing agent count for the fourth quarter was 1,539, down 2% from a year ago, and down 3% from the third quarter. The producing agent count at Liberty National ended the quarter at 1,478. We expect the producing agent count to be in the range of 1,550 to 1,625 at the end of 2016.
Life net sales for the full year 2015 grew 4%. Life net sales growth is expected to be within the range of 4% to 7% for the full year 2016. 
Health net sales for the full year 2015 grew 4%. Health net sales growth is expected to be within a range of 2% to 4% in 2016.
At Family Heritage, health premiums increased 8% to $57 million, up underwriting margin increased 2% to $11 million. Health net sales were up 2% to $12 million. The average agent -- the average producing agent count for the fourth quarter was 877, up 12% from a year ago but down 3% from the third quarter. The producing agent count at the end of the quarter was 911. We expect the producing agent count to be in the range of 975 to 1,000 at the end of 2016. Health sales for the full year 2015 grew 7%. We expect health sales growth to be in the range of 5% to 9% for the full year 2016.
At United American General agency, health premiums increased 12% to $90 million. Net health sales declined from $51 million to $38 million. Individual sales grew 49% to $18 million. Our group sales declined 47% to $21 million. 
Individual Medicare supplement sales for the full year 2015 grew 36%. For the full year 2016, we expect growth in individual Medicare supplements sales to be around 8% to 10%. I will now turn the call back to Gary.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to spend a few minutes discussing our investment operations. First, excess investment income. Excess investment income, which we define as net investment income less acquired interest on policy, liabilities and debt, was $54 million compared to $55
componenttext:
I want to spend a few minutes discussing our investment operations. First, excess investment income. Excess investment income, which we define as net investment income less acquired interest on policy, liabilities and debt, was $54 million compared to $55 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. On a per share basis, reflecting the impact of our share repurchase program, excess investment income was flat.
As discussed on previous calls, the Part D segment has had a negative impact on excess investment income due to negative cash flows that occurred during the year, including the long delay of receiving reimbursements from CMS for excess claims paid by the company. The impact of the loss investment income from the delayed receipt of reimbursements is reflected in income from continuing operations rather than discontinued operations, in accordance the applicable accounting rules. 
In 2015, Part D had a negative impact on excess investment income of approximately $8 million. In 2016, we expect excess investment income to grow by about 1% to 3%. However, on a per share basis, we should see the increase of about 6% to 8%. 
At the midpoint of our 2016 guidance, we're expecting a drag on excess investment income from Part D of approximately $8 million to $9 million.
Now regarding the investment portfolio. Invested assets were $13.8 billion, including $13.3 billion of fixed maturities and amortized costs. At the fixed maturities, $12.6 billion are investment grade, with an average rating of A minus. And below investment grade bonds were $640 million, compared to $561 million a year ago. The percentage of below investment grade bonds to fixed maturities is 4.8% compared to 4.4% a year ago.
With a portfolio leverage of 3.6x, the percentage of below investment grade bonds to equity, excluding net unrealized gains on fixed maturities, is 17%. Overall, the total portfolio is rated A, same as a year ago. In addition, we have net unrealized gains in the fixed maturity portfolio of $506 million, approximately $408 million less than at the end of the third quarter.
To complete the investment portfolio discussion, I'd like to address our $1.6 billion of fixed maturities in the energy sector. As a result of spreads widening in the fourth quarter, the net unrealized loss of our energy portfolio increased by $122 million to a total of $165 million at December 31. However, we believe the risk of realizing a losses in the foreseeable future is minimal for the following reasons. $1.5 billion or 94% of our energy holdings are investment grade. Only $143 million or 9% of our energy holdings are in the oilfield service and drilling sector. Approximately 70% of these bonds are investment grade. 
Also, based on the consensus of expert views, our investment believes that oil is more likely to increase to $45 to $50 a barrel during the next 12 to 24 months as they remain at current levels. We believe the company portfolio can continue to operate for very long time with oil prices at $45 to $50 a barrel. Even if oil remains around $30 a barrel for the next 12 to 24 months, we would not expect to have any defaults during that period.
Finally, the copies we have invested in have a variety of options that they can utilize to avoid default, including but not limited to, reducing distributions to partners, drawing of lines of credits and reducing exploration activities. Now we do believe that there can be further downgrades, which could pressure our RBC ratio. However, that doesn't mean we would have to suspend or materially impact our stock buyback program. Frank will address this in more detail when he discusses capital. 
Now investment yield in the fourth quarter, we invested $341 million in investment-grade fixed maturities, primarily in the industrial sector. We invested at an average yield of 5%, an average rating of A- and an average life of 26 years. For the entire portfolio, the fourth quarter yield was 5.81%, down 8 basis points from the 5.89% yield in the fourth quarter of 2014. At December 31, the portfolio yield was approximately 5.83%. The midpoint of our current guidance for 2016 assumes increasing money yield throughout the year, averaging 5.25% for the full year.
We continue to hope for higher interest rates. As discussed on previous analyst calls, rising new money rates will have a positive impact on operating income by driving up excess investment income. We are not concerned about potential unrealized losses that are interest rate driven reflected on the balance sheet, since we would not expect to convert them to realized losses. we got to be intent, and more important, the ability to hold our investments through. However, if rates don't rise, a continued lower interest rate environment will impact our income statement but not the balance sheet. This would primarily sell noninterest-sensitive protection products accounted for under FAS 60. We don't see a reasonable scenario that would require us to write-off DAC or to put up additional GAAP reserves due to interest rate fluctuations. In addition, we do not foresee a negative impact on our statutory balance sheet.
We're we will benefit from higher interest rates, Torchmark will continue to earn substantial excess investment income in an extended low-interest-rate environment.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. First, I want to spend a few minutes discussing our share repurchases and capital position. In the fourth quarter, we spent $83 million to buy 1.4 million Torchmark shares at an average price of $58.68. For the full year, we spent $359 milli
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. First, I want to spend a few minutes discussing our share repurchases and capital position. In the fourth quarter, we spent $83 million to buy 1.4 million Torchmark shares at an average price of $58.68. For the full year, we spent $359 million of parent company cash to acquire 6.3 million shares at an average price of $56.99.
The parent ended the year with liquid assets of $46 million. In addition to these liquid assets, the parent will generate additional free cash flow during the remainder of 2016. Free cash flow results primarily from the dividends received by the parent from the subsidiaries less the interest paid on debt and the dividends paid to Torchmark shareholders.
While our 2015 statutory earnings have not yet been finalized, we expect free cash flow in 2016 to be in the range of $320 million to $330 million. Thus, included in the $46 million available from assets on hand at the beginning of the year, we currently expect to have $366 million to $376 million of cash and liquid assets available to the parent during the year. This level of free cash flow in 2016 is lower than recent years, due to lower distributable statutory earnings at our subsidiaries in 2015. 
As we've discussed on prior calls, a key driver of the lower earnings is higher commission and acquisition expenses associated with the higher levels of sales growth we have experienced in 2014 and 2015, coupled with lower growth rates and investment income due to lower new money yields and adverse Part D cash flows. Another significant driver of the lower earnings is higher federal income tax expense in 2015 as compared to 2014. 
At this time, we anticipate that statutory earnings in 2016 will be approximately the same as 2015, as the profits from recent sales start to emerge. The incremental impact of new sales lessons and the growth and investment income improves. As noted before, we will use our cash as efficiently as possible. If market conditions are favorable, we expect that share repurchases will continue to be a primary use of those funds. We also expect to retain approximately if the million dollars to search and $60 million of assets of the parent company, absence the need to utilize any of these funds to support our insurance company operations.
Now regarding RBC at our insurance subsidiaries. We currently plan to maintain our capital at the level necessary to retain our current ratings. For the last 3 years, that level has been around. And NAIC RBC ratio of 325% on a consolidated basis. This ratio is lower than some peer companies, but is sufficient for our companies in light of our consistent statutory earnings, the relatively lower risk of our policy liabilities and our ratings. Although we have not finalized our 2015 statutory financial statements, we expect that the RBC percentage at December 31, 2015, will be around the the 325% consolidated target. We do not anticipate any changes to our targeted RBC levels in 2016.
Our investment department has reviewed multiple scenarios of downgrades within our fixed maturity holdings, including those in the energy sector. 
To put their findings in the context, as a rule of thumb, downgrades of around $100 million in statutory book value would reduce our RBC ratio by approximately 2 percentage points and require around $9 million of additional capital to retain a 325% RBC level. Using this rule of thumb, and to the extent additional downgrade do occur in 2016, we are comfortable that we would be able to fund the additional capital requirements with available assets on hand and other sources of liquidity available to Torchmark without having to suspend or reduce the amount available for buybacks. 
Now, a few comments to provide an update on our Medicare Part D operations. Management has committed to a plan to sell the Part D business and expected to be sold before the end of the year. We have met the criteria to account for the business as held for sale, and the results of the Part D operations will be reflected within discontinued operations in our financial statements. As we have previously said, we originally decided to participate in the Medicare Part D program back in 2006 because most of the underwriting risks was covered by the government, and we believe that it would complement our Medicare supplement business. 
Over the years, the Part D business has been good for Torchmark as it has provided over $259 million of underwriting margin since 2006. However, this business have been changing rapidly over the past few years, and earnings have become much more volatile. Increased competition, industry consolidation and preferred net worth have reduced overall margins and made a more difficult for smaller players to compete in this market. While we are still generating profits from the Part D operations, this profits have been shrinking in recent years due to higher direct costs and increased administrative and compliance costs. We believe this trend will likely continue and perhaps, could even turning to significant losses in the future as drug costs, especially those in specialty drugs, continued to escalate. In addition, we've already seen regulatory changes that have shifted cost from the government to carriers, and appears likely that more cost shifting is to come. Overall, the risks and the administrative and compliance costs associated with the business are much greater than they once were and the business now demands and increasingly disproportionate amount of time and focus, given its level of earnings. 
Looking forward, we prefer to focus our attention on our core license insurance businesses and other lines of health business that produce more predictable stable margins. We've previously indicated that we view this business opportunistically and that we would review it on a really basis. While the Part D business has been a good opportunity to this point, we no longer believe that it is a business that make sense for Torchmark going forward. And therefore, it is the right time to exit the business. 
We have included in our website a final operating summary for the discontinued operation. For the year, we earned $10.8 million or $0.09 per share after tax. This amount was lower than we had anticipated on the last call due to higher-than-expected claims in the fourth quarter as a result of higher drug costs. To the extent we were to hold the business for the full year 2016, we estimate that our after-tax earnings would be in the range of $5 million to $9 million. As noted in our previous calls, the profits from the Part D business are further reduced by lost investment income, the results from having to finance substantial cash outflows during the year, including amounts paid upfront on behalf of the government that won't get repaid to us until the following year. These outflows are generally represented by the significant receivable balances that are included in the assets held-for-sale line of our consolidated balance sheet. 
The opportunity cost of not being able to timely invest the receivable balances is included in our continuing operations, as required by the applicable accounting rules. However, to reflect what management considers to be a better reflection of earnings from the Part D operations, we have included on our website a schedule showing the pro forma income from discontinued operations and includes an estimate of the after-tax cost of the forgot investment income. As we are in the midst of discussions with multiple parties regarding a purchase, we are unable to discuss the timing, potential value or other details of the sale. However, we do anticipate that the assets held for sale on our balance sheet will be fully recovered and do not believe the consummation of the sale will have a material impact on our income from continuing operations. 
Any such an impact on earnings is included in the range of earnings guidance provided.
Now with respect to our guidance for 2016. On our last call, we indicated a preliminary range of $4.25 to $4.55 for our 2016 net operating earnings per share with a midpoint of $4.40. Excluding the effect of the discontinued Part D operations, the midpoint would have been $4.35. We now estimate our earnings from continuing operations will be in the range of $4.28 to $4.48, a 6.1% growth at the midpoint over our 2015 earnings from continuing operations. A schedule providing prior year earnings per share for continued operations only and our revised 2016 earnings per share guidance has been placed on our website. Those are my comments. I will now turn the call back to Larry.

componenttext: Sure, as indicated in my comments that we kind of looked at and have that rule of thumb that roughly $100 million of downgrades would extrapolate into  probably needing about $9 million of additional capital retained at current RBC levels. And so, with the cash available at the holding company or as I've said, from being able to access capital markets that we would have sources available to make for additional capital contributions at the company if we needed to. Using that rule of thumb if we were to have around $500 million of downgrades, which is about half of the BBB energy bonds that we have out there, that would indicate that we would only need around $50 million of additional capital to retain our existing RBC levels.

componenttext: Eric, I was going to say Frank is right, why we use lower-cost approach, if you're talking about $50 million, you can use the cash on hand or we can borrow short-term at a very low-cost. To us, that's a much lower cost than reducing the dividend, amount of our dividend to the parent company.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. That 52% was what we have there in Q4 and for the year as a whole, we have the obligation percentage of about 51%, which was right at the top edge of what we had estimated for 2015. I think for 2016, we previously indicated, without all of the obligations will be around the 52%, probably move that up slightly somewhere in that 52.5% range is kind of what we have anticipate for the policy obligations and we're still releasing in our -- the overall margin percentage on a Direct Response business in '16 being somewhere in that 19. % to 20% range, pretty much than we have previously indicated, haven't really seen a lot of change in that at this point.

componenttext: Well, we really would be -- have responsibilities for the business up until the time of sale, unless there's some other arrangement with a buyer from that perspective. But I think the point was from an RBC perspective, the way that the RBC rules work, if we sold it now or partway through the year, you don't get 100% reduction of that at the end of 2016. Some of that bleeds over into 2017. And then of course, we're settling up even in '17 just with respect to or potentially, we could be settling up in '17. I'm just receiving payments, and again, just depending on how the sales process and what arrangements will work out with the buyer.

componenttext: Randy, as far as where we're placing our money, I mentioned it's primarily industrial sector and that's where it's been for the last 2 or 3 quarters. Within that, it's mostly been in the consumer sector. The transportation, some of the other industrial sectors, we haven't really added to our energy exposure. As far as derisking, we don't see, at this point, a need to sell any of our bonds. Again, let's talk about energy because that's what people mostly is concerned is. We feel confident in the bonds that we have, and we expect that so we don't expect to sell those. In the last few years, we have, I think, done a good job of spreading the risk of we were a little overweight on financials a few years ago. I think we're pleased with where we are with our distribution by sector.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the I guess decline in cash flow for 2016 relative to really the last 3 years. Can you help just walk through the drivers of that? I know a lot of it is sales driven, but if you could give us a little bit more granularity as
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the I guess decline in cash flow for 2016 relative to really the last 3 years. Can you help just walk through the drivers of that? I know a lot of it is sales driven, but if you could give us a little bit more granularity as well as price the step down in cash flow.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, again, I've indicated think there's some couple of key drivers that all kind of work together to push that down. But you do have the higher sales and you talk about the higher sales and in the first year of those sales, acquisition expenses e
componenttext: Yes. I mean, again, I've indicated think there's some couple of key drivers that all kind of work together to push that down. But you do have the higher sales and you talk about the higher sales and in the first year of those sales, acquisition expenses exceed the amount of premiums coming in, so there is a drag on your statutory earnings from those. And then you start having positive statutory incomes in that second year after the sale. But as you continue to do -- as we the last couple of years, where we had 2 really good years of continued sales growth, that's just pulling down the amount of statutory income and that we anticipate those future profits from those sales to start really emerging coming in the future here. But that's probably generating somewhere in that $15 million to $20 million of statutory drag in 2015 just by itself. And then on the normal years you'll have with increase in investment income that would help to offset that. But unfortunately, the last couple of years, with the continuing drag that we have had, largely from the Part D, and of course, lower interest rates, and to some degree, the higher direct response claims we've been having growth in that investment income up only around a 2% or probably above the 2% level rather than at that 4% so invested assets are growing at. So that's weighing in on it. We have talked about it a little bit about some higher acquisition, administrative costs, just in growth in 2015 from some of our IT and pension costs and that type of thing. And then the way that the accounting rules work for federal income taxes. Basically, you don't get quite the smoothing effect that you have on for GAAP purposes, and we just and the having's higher taxes in 2015 here than we did on a comparable basis in 2014.

componenttextpreview: All right. Then last one. Can you just discuss how the impairment policy works from a pricing standpoint? So if you fully intend to hold a security to maturity but the bond let's say is trading at $0.50 to $1 for an extended period of time, is there any r
componenttext: All right. Then last one. Can you just discuss how the impairment policy works from a pricing standpoint? So if you fully intend to hold a security to maturity but the bond let's say is trading at $0.50 to $1 for an extended period of time, is there any reason that require you to potentially impair that facility fee is to thank it will pay off that for?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, and the answer to your question. In fact, it's just trading below book value in and of itself even from an extended period of time wouldn't require us to impair that security, we would have to take a look and evaluate that particular bond offering and
componenttext: No, and the answer to your question. In fact, it's just trading below book value in and of itself even from an extended period of time wouldn't require us to impair that security, we would have to take a look and evaluate that particular bond offering and determine, do we think it's money good. And as long as you believe that we're going to collect that, the principal amount from that and in our particular case, we have the ability and the intent to hold those to maturities. So as long as we believe and can demonstrate that we will be able to collect that at maturity, that way that have to have an impairment on the accounting rules.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's really more of a timing issue there because if you compare the 2 quarters, the reason for the higher margin is that we had lower positive obligations fourth quarter '15. as it turned out, Fourth quarter '14 is our highest policy obligation quart
componenttext: Bob, it's really more of a timing issue there because if you compare the 2 quarters, the reason for the higher margin is that we had lower positive obligations fourth quarter '15. as it turned out, Fourth quarter '14 is our highest policy obligation quarter and fourth quarter '15 was the lowest for the year 2015. If you look at it on a year-to-date basis, 2015 was 38% of premium versus 39% of premium the year before, so it's pretty much the same. Our outlook for the coming years is that we'll only be at around 38% level and our margins will be somewhere I think at the midpoint about 26.5% and that's a little bit lower than 2015 but the little bit higher than 2014.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Torchmark Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mike Majors, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, si
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Torchmark Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mike Majors, VP of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Joining the call today are Gary Coleman and Larry Hutchison, our Co-Chief Executive Officers; Frank Svoboda, our Chief Financial Officer; and Brian Mitchell, our General Counsel.Some of our comments or answers to your
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Joining the call today are Gary Coleman and Larry Hutchison, our Co-Chief Executive Officers; Frank Svoboda, our Chief Financial Officer; and Brian Mitchell, our General Counsel.
Some of our comments or answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements that are provided for general guidance purposes only. Accordingly, please refer to our 2014 10-K and any subsequent Forms 10-Q on filed with the SEC. 
I will now turn the call over to Gary Coleman.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. In the fourth quarter, net operating income from all operations was $131 million or $1.05 per share, a per share increase of 5% from a year ago. During the fourth quarter, management determined that the Part D
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. In the fourth quarter, net operating income from all operations was $131 million or $1.05 per share, a per share increase of 5% from a year ago. During the fourth quarter, management determined that the Part D business met the criteria to be held for sale and has classified it as discontinued operations. 
Net operating income from continuing operations, which excludes Part D, was $131 million or $1.05 per share, up 6% on a per share basis from a year ago. Net income for the quarter was $133 million or $1.07 per share, a 5% decline on a per share basis. The decline was due primarily to the fact that we had $11 million of tax-driven realized losses in the fourth quarter of this year compared to a gain of $5 million in the year-ago quarter.
With fixed maturities at amortized cost, our return on equity as of December 31 was 14.5% and our book value per share was $30.09, an 8% increase from a year ago. 
On a GAAP reported basis, with fixed maturities at market value, book value per share was $32.71, a decline of 10% from a year ago. 
In our life insurance operations, premium revenue grew 5.5% to $521 million while life underwriting margin was $145 million, up 6.3% from a year ago. Net life sales increased 2% to $99 million. 
On the health side, premium revenue grew 5% to $235 million and health underwriting margin was up $51 million, approximately the same as a year ago. Health sales declined 17% to $60 million due to declining group sales. Individual health sales were $38 million, up 20%. 
Administrative expenses were $48 million for the quarter, up 9% from a year ago, and in line with our expectations. As a percentage of premium from continuing operations, administrative expenses were 6.3% compared to 6.1% a year ago. The primary reasons for the increase in administrative expenses are higher information technology and pension costs. 
For the full year, administrative expenses were $186 million or 6.2% of premium. In 2016, we expect administrative expenses to grow approximately 5% and to remain around 6.2% of premium.
I will now turn the call over to Larry Hutchison for his comments on the marketing operations.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary. I will now go over the results for each company.At American Income, life premiums were up 8% to $213 million, and life underwriting margin was up 10% to $69 million. Net life sales were $50 million, up 9%, due primarily to increased age
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary. I will now go over the results for each company.
At American Income, life premiums were up 8% to $213 million, and life underwriting margin was up 10% to $69 million. Net life sales were $50 million, up 9%, due primarily to increased agent productivity. 
The average agent count for the fourth quarter was 6,590, up 4% over a year ago, but approximately the same as the third quarter. The producing agent count at the end of the fourth quarter was 6,552. We expect the producing agent count to be in the range of 6,600 to 6,800 at the end of 2016. Life sales for the full year 2015 grew 15%. We expect 5% to 7% life sales growth in 2016.
In our Direct Response operation at Global Life, life premiums were up 7%, $185 million. Life underwriting margin declined 2% to $37 million. Net life sales were down 3% to $37 million. Life sales for the full year of 2015 grew 4%. We expect life sales to be flat or down slightly in 2016. 
At Liberty National, life premiums were $67 million, approximately the same as the year-ago quarter. Life underwriting margin was $19 million, up 24%. Net life sales decreased 5% to $9 million. Net health sales decreased 4% to $5 million. The average producing agent count for the fourth quarter was 1,539, down 2% from a year ago, and down 3% from the third quarter. The producing agent count at Liberty National ended the quarter at 1,478. We expect the producing agent count to be in the range of 1,550 to 1,625 at the end of 2016.
Life net sales for the full year 2015 grew 4%. Life net sales growth is expected to be within the range of 4% to 7% for the full year 2016. 
Health net sales for the full year 2015 grew 4%. Health net sales growth is expected to be within a range of 2% to 4% in 2016.
At Family Heritage, health premiums increased 8% to $57 million, health underwriting margin increased 2% to $11 million. Health net sales were up 2% to $12 million. The average agent -- the average agent -- the average producing agent count for the fourth quarter was 877, up 12% from a year ago, but down 3% from the third quarter. The producing agent count at the end of the quarter was 911. We expect the producing agent count to be in the range of 975 to 1,000 at the end of 2016. Health sales for the full year 2015 grew 7%. We expect health sales growth to be in the range of 5% to 9% for the full year 2016.
At United American General Agency, health premiums increased 12% to $90 million. Net health sales declined from $51 million to $38 million. Individual sales grew 49% to $18 million. Our group sales declined 47% to $21 million. 
Individual Medicare supplement sales for the full year 2015 grew 36%. For the full year 2016, we expect growth in individual Medicare supplement sales to be around 8% to 10%. 
I'll now turn the call back to Gary.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to spend a few minutes discussing our investment operations. First, the excess investment income. Excess investment income, which we define as net investment income less acquired interest on policy liabilities and debt, was $54 million compared to
componenttext:
I want to spend a few minutes discussing our investment operations. First, the excess investment income. Excess investment income, which we define as net investment income less acquired interest on policy liabilities and debt, was $54 million compared to $55 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. On a per share basis, reflecting the impact of our share repurchase program, excess investment income was flat.
As discussed on previous calls, the Part D segment has had a negative impact on excess investment income due to negative cash flows that occurred during the year, including the long delay receiving reimbursements from CMS for excess claims paid by the company. The impact of the loss investment income from the delayed receipt of reimbursements is reflected in income from continuing operations rather than discontinued operations, in accordance with applicable accounting rules. 
In 2015, Part D had a negative impact on excess investment income of approximately $8 million. In 2016, we expect excess investment income to grow by about 1% to 3%. However, on a per share basis, we should see the increase of about 6% to 8%. 
At the midpoint of our 2016 guidance, we're expecting a drag on excess investment income from Part D of approximately $8 million to $9 million.
Now regarding the investment portfolio. Invested assets were $13.8 billion, including $13.3 billion of fixed maturities and amortized costs. At the fixed maturities, $12.6 billion are investment grade, with an average rating of A-. And below investment grade bonds were $640 million compared to $561 million a year ago. The percentage of below investment grade bonds to fixed maturities is 4.8% compared to 4.4% a year ago.
With a portfolio leverage of 3.6x, the percentage of below investment grade bonds to equity, excluding net unrealized gains on fixed maturities, is 17%. Overall, the total portfolio is rated A-, same as a year ago. In addition, we have net unrealized gains in the fixed maturity portfolio of $506 million, approximately $408 million less than at the end of the third quarter.
To complete the investment portfolio discussion, I'd like to address our $1.6 billion of fixed maturities in the energy sector. As a result of spreads widening in the fourth quarter, the net unrealized loss of our energy portfolio increased by $122 million to a total of $165 million at December 31. However, we believe the risk of realizing any losses in the foreseeable future is minimal for the following reasons: $1.5 billion or 94% of our energy holdings are investment grade; only $143 million or 9% of our energy holdings are in the oilfield service and drilling sector. Approximately 70% of these bonds are investment grade. 
Also, based on the consensus of expert views, our investment department believes that oil is more likely to increase to $45 or $50 a barrel during the next 12 to 24 months as they remain at current levels. We believe the companies in our portfolio can continue to operate for very long time with oil prices at $45 to $50 a barrel. Even if oil remains around $30 a barrel for the next 12 to 24 months, we would not expect to have any defaults during that period.
Finally, the companies we have invested in have a variety of options that they can utilize to avoid default including, but not limited to, reducing distributions to partners, drawing of lines of credits and reducing exploration activities. Now we do believe that there could be further downgrades which could pressure our RBC ratio. However, that doesn't mean we would have to suspend or materially impact our stock buyback program. Frank will address this in more detail when he discusses capital. 
Now as to investment yield. In the fourth quarter, we invested $341 million in investment grade fixed maturities, primarily in the industrial sector. We invested at an average yield of 5%, an average rating of A- and an average life of 26 years. For the entire portfolio, the fourth quarter yield was 5.81%, down 8 basis points from the 5.89% yield in the fourth quarter of 2014. At December 31, the portfolio yield was approximately 5.83%. The midpoint of our current guidance for 2016 assumes increasing money yield throughout the year, averaging 5.25% for the full year.
We continue to hope for higher interest rates. As discussed on previous analyst calls, rising new money rates will have a positive impact on operating income by driving up excess investment income. We are not concerned about potential unrealized losses that are interest rate driven reflected on the balance sheet since we'd not expect to convert them to realized losses. We got to be intent, and more important, the ability to hold our investments through maturity. However, if rates don't rise, a continued lower interest rate environment will impact our income statement, but not the balance sheet. This would primarily sell noninterest-sensitive protection products accounted for under FAS 60. We don't see a reasonable scenario that would require us to write off DAC or to put up additional GAAP reserves due to interest rate fluctuations. In addition, we do not foresee a negative impact on our statutory balance sheet.
While we would benefit from higher interest rates, Torchmark would continue to earn substantial excess investment income in an extended low interest rate environment.
Now I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. First, I want to spend a few minutes discussing our share repurchases and capital position. In the fourth quarter, we spent $83 million to buy 1.4 million Torchmark shares at an average price of $58.68. For the full year, we spent $359 milli
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. First, I want to spend a few minutes discussing our share repurchases and capital position. In the fourth quarter, we spent $83 million to buy 1.4 million Torchmark shares at an average price of $58.68. For the full year, we spent $359 million of parent company cash to acquire 6.3 million shares at an average price of $56.99.
The parent ended the year with liquid assets of $46 million. In addition to these liquid assets, the parent will generate additional free cash flow during the remainder of 2016. Free cash flow results primarily from the dividends received by the parent from the subsidiaries less the interest paid on debt and the dividends paid to Torchmark shareholders.
While our 2015 statutory earnings have not yet been finalized, we expect free cash flow in 2016 to be in the range of $320 million to $330 million. Thus, including the $46 million available from assets on hand at the beginning of the year, we currently expect to have $366 million to $376 million of cash and liquid assets available to the parent during the year. This level of free cash flow in 2016 is lower than recent years, due to lower distributable statutory earnings at our subsidiaries in 2015. 
As we've discussed on prior calls, a key driver of the lower earnings is higher commission and acquisition expenses associated with the higher levels of sales growth we have experienced in 2014 and 2015, coupled with lower growth rates and investment income due to lower new money yields and adverse Part D cash flows. Another significant driver of the lower earnings is higher federal income tax expense in 2015 as compared to 2014. 
At this time, we anticipate that statutory earnings in 2016 will be approximately the same as 2015, as the profits from recent sales start to emerge. The incremental impact of new sales lessons and the growth and investment income improves. As noted before, we will use our cash as efficiently as possible. If market conditions are favorable, we expect that share repurchases will continue to be a primary use of those funds. We also expect to retain approximately $50 million to $60 million of assets at the parent company, absent the need to utilize any of these funds to support our insurance company operations.
Now regarding RBC at our insurance subsidiaries. We currently plan to maintain our capital at the level necessary to retain our current ratings. For the last 3 years, that level has been around an NAIC RBC ratio of 325% on a consolidated basis. This ratio is lower than some peer companies, but is sufficient for our companies in light of our consistent statutory earnings, the relatively lower risk of our policy liabilities and our ratings. Although we have not finalized our 2015 statutory financial statements, we expect that the RBC percentage at December 31, 2015, would be around the 325% consolidated target. We do not anticipate any changes to our targeted RBC levels in 2016.
Our investment department has reviewed multiple scenarios of downgrades within our fixed maturity holdings, including those in the energy sector. 
To put their findings into context, as a rule of thumb, downgrades of around $100 million in statutory book value would reduce our RBC ratio by approximately 2 percentage points and require around $9 million of additional capital to retain a 325% RBC level. Using this rule of thumb, and to the extent additional downgrades do occur in 2016, we are comfortable that we would be able to fund the additional capital requirements with available assets on hand and other sources of liquidity available to Torchmark without having to suspend or reduce the amount available for buybacks. 
Now a few comments to provide an update on our Medicare Part D operations. Management has committed to a plan to sell the Part D business and expect it to be sold before the end of the year. We have met the criteria to account for the business as held for sale, and the results of the Part D operations will be reflected within discontinued operations in our financial statements. As we have previously said, we originally decided to participate in the Medicare Part D program back in 2006 because most of the underwriting risks was covered by the government, and we believe that it would complement our Medicare supplement business. 
Over the years, the Part D business has been good for Torchmark as it has provided over $259 million of underwriting margin since 2006. However, this business has been changing rapidly over the past few years and the earnings have become much more volatile. Increased competition, industry consolidation and preferred networks have reduced overall margins and made it more difficult for smaller players to compete in this market. While we are still generating profits from the Part D operations, these profits have been shrinking in recent years due to higher direct costs and increased administrative and compliance costs. We believe this trend will likely continue and perhaps could even turning to significant losses in the future as drug costs, especially those on specialty drugs, continued to escalate. In addition, we have already seen regulatory changes that have shifted costs from the government to carriers, and appears likely that more cost shifting is to come. Overall, the risks and the administrative and compliance costs associated with the business are much greater than they once were and the business now demands an increasingly disproportionate amount of time and focus given its level of earnings. 
Looking forward, we prefer to focus our attention on our core life insurance businesses and other lines of health business that produce more predictable stable margins. We've previously indicated that we view this business opportunistically and that we would review it on a yearly basis. While the Part D business has been a good opportunity to this point, we no longer believe that it is a business that make sense for Torchmark going forward. And therefore, it is the right time to exit the business. 
We have included on our website a final operating summary for the discontinued operations. For the year, we earned $10.8 million or $0.09 per share after tax. This amount was lower than we had anticipated on the last call due to higher than expected claims in the fourth quarter as a result of higher drug costs. To the extent we were to hold the business for the full year 2016, we estimate that our after tax earnings would be in the range of $5 million to $9 million. As noted on our previous calls, the profits from the Part D business are further reduced by lost investment income that results from having to finance substantial cash outflows during the year, including amounts paid upfront on behalf of the government that won't get repaid to us until the following year. These outflows are generally represented by the significant receivable balances that are included in the assets held for sale line of our consolidated balance sheet. 
The opportunity cost of not being able to timely invest the receivable balances is included in our continuing operations, as required by the applicable accounting rules. However, to reflect what management considers to be a better reflection of earnings from the Part D operations, we have included on our website a schedule showing the pro forma income from discontinued operations that includes an estimate of the after tax costs of the forgone investment income. As we are in the midst of discussions with multiple parties regarding a purchase, we are unable to discuss the timing, potential value or other details of the sale. However, we do anticipate that the assets held for sale on our balance sheet will be fully recovered and do not believe the consummation of the sale will have a material impact on our income from continuing operations. Any such impact on earnings is included in the range of earnings guidance provided.
And with respect to our guidance for 2016. On our last call, we indicated a preliminary range of $4.25 to $4.55 for our 2016 net operating earnings per share with a midpoint of $4.40. Excluding the effect of the discontinued Part D operations, the midpoint would have been $4.35. We now estimate that our earnings from continuing operations will be in the range of $4.28 to $4.48, a 6.1% growth at the midpoint over our 2015 earnings from continued operations. A schedule providing prior year earnings per share for continued operations only and our revised 2016 earnings per share guidance has been placed on our website. 
Those are my comments. I will now turn the call back to Larry.

componenttext: Yes. I think in looking at the increase at the midpoint, we really have an improved outlook on life and underwriting margins, underwriting income overall. And there's a slight margin improvement at Liberty National, given the favorable claims experience that we had in Q4. And then, really, the high -- the really favorable sales that we had at American Income is, well, just better expectations with respect to some of our premium at Direct Response really impact the 2016 guidance. You need to remember that the -- some of the reduced sales guidance, with respect to 2016, really don't impact the 2016 premiums as much as they will premiums looking out past that.

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then you talked about expecting new money yields going up a bit over the course of 2016, or, at least, that being one of your underlying assumptions. What's that based on here? Is it spread widening? Is it opportunity you see in the market?

componenttext: It's a little bit of both. It's -- we're expecting it is -- from our investment department canvassing all reports coming with a consensus, expect the treasury rate to almost decline so far in January. We'd expect it to gradually increase during the year. The spreads, we're pretty much expecting to start where they were towards the end of 2015.

componenttext: Yes. There will be eventually some of the capital freed up. We do have to carry some RBC on that business. We would estimate we'd probably carry. We don't have the final RBC for 2015 done yet, but with respect to that business, but we would expect it to be somewhere maybe in that $60 million to $70 million of capital ultimately we hold on that business. We would see that capital being freed up over the course of 2016 and then partially -- and then more fully over the course of 2017.

componenttext: So the expectation would be then they'd be deployed within 2017, '18?

componenttext: Yes. And it's always a possibility that we would be able to deploy that capital or we'd be able to distribute some of that excess capital. But we'd really have to be able to see what the capital situation looks like at that point in time, but probably really wouldn't be fully available, if you will, into that 2017, 2018 time frame.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on the business. Your Direct Response sales were weak, and I think you're expecting a flat -- or sort of flattish sales in 2016 off of just 4% growth in 2015. So maybe talk about what's going on there, whether it's because of the market envi
componenttext: And then just on the business. Your Direct Response sales were weak, and I think you're expecting a flat -- or sort of flattish sales in 2016 off of just 4% growth in 2015. So maybe talk about what's going on there, whether it's because of the market environment or is it more some of the changes that you're making, given what's happened with your margins in that business.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jimmy, as we've discussed previously, we've experienced lower than expected profit margins associated with prescription drug underwriting changes. So sales have been lower since we've now adjusted our marketing activities to eliminate the segments of unpr
componenttext: Jimmy, as we've discussed previously, we've experienced lower than expected profit margins associated with prescription drug underwriting changes. So sales have been lower since we've now adjusted our marketing activities to eliminate the segments of unprofitable sales.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Erik Bass with Citi.p id="225933251" name="Erik Bass" type="A" />Could you just elaborate a little bit on your comment about if you do see ratings downgrades you think that you could use some assets on hand or oth
componenttext:
And we'll take our next question from Erik Bass with Citi.
p id="225933251" name="Erik Bass" type="A" />
Could you just elaborate a little bit on your comment about if you do see ratings downgrades you think that you could use some assets on hand or other measures to kind of plug the RBC impact. Can you just expand on that a little bit?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I indicated in the -- in my comments that we kind of looked and have that rule of thumb that roughly $100 million of downgrades would extrapolate into probably needing about an additional $9 million of additional capital retained at current RBC l
componenttext: Sure. As I indicated in the -- in my comments that we kind of looked and have that rule of thumb that roughly $100 million of downgrades would extrapolate into probably needing about an additional $9 million of additional capital retained at current RBC levels. And so whether it be the cash that's available at the holding company or, as we've said, from being able to access the capital markets that we would have sources available to make for additional capital contribution to the company if we needed to. Using that rule of thumb, if we were to have around $500 million of downgrades, which is about half of the BBB energy bonds that we have out there, that would really indicate that we would only need around $50 million of additional capital to retain our existing RBC levels.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And obviously, one option would be to just not dividend that out as well. So I think -- were you implying that you don't expect any change to the free cash flow guidance? Or could the free cash flow be lower in that scenario?
componenttext: Got it. And obviously, one option would be to just not dividend that out as well. So I think -- were you implying that you don't expect any change to the free cash flow guidance? Or could the free cash flow be lower in that scenario?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Always a possibility, but we would always be looking at the opportunities and looking for the cheapest or most inexpensive way for our shareholders to fund that additional capital.
componenttext: Always a possibility, but we would always be looking at the opportunities and looking for the cheapest or most inexpensive way for our shareholders to fund that additional capital.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. [indiscernible] Sorry.
componenttext: Got it. [indiscernible] Sorry.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Erik, I was just going to say Frank is right. We'd probably use the lower cost approach. And if you're talking about $50 million, we could use the cash on hand or we could borrow short term at a very low cost. To us, that's a much lower cost than reducing
componenttext: Erik, I was just going to say Frank is right. We'd probably use the lower cost approach. And if you're talking about $50 million, we could use the cash on hand or we could borrow short term at a very low cost. To us, that's a much lower cost than reducing the dividend, the amount we're dividending to the parent company.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then just one question on Direct Response policy obligations. I think, as a percentage of premiums, they were slightly above the 52% range that you're targeting for next year. Just any comments there and what gives you confiden
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just one question on Direct Response policy obligations. I think, as a percentage of premiums, they were slightly above the 52% range that you're targeting for next year. Just any comments there and what gives you confidence that, that kind of ratio will come down over the next year?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That -- right, that 52% was what we had there in Q4. And for the year as a whole, we had the obligation percentage of around 51%, which was right at the top edge of what we had estimated for 2015. I think, for 2016, we'd previously indicated, we thou
componenttext: Yes. That -- right, that 52% was what we had there in Q4. And for the year as a whole, we had the obligation percentage of around 51%, which was right at the top edge of what we had estimated for 2015. I think, for 2016, we'd previously indicated, we thought the policy obligations would be around that 52%, probably move that up slightly somewhere in that 52.5% range is kind of what we would anticipate for the policy obligations. And we're still really seeing our -- the overall margin percentage on the Direct Response business in '16 being somewhere in that 19.5% to 20% range, pretty much what we had previously indicated. We haven't really seen a lot of change in that at this point.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Steven Schwartz with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Steven Schwartz with Raymond James.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, just a couple, I guess, on Part D. It sounds -- maybe it's the nature of the Part D business, but it sounds to me from the conversation that just occurred with regards to when capital would be released that you kind of will remain on the books -- o
componenttext: First, just a couple, I guess, on Part D. It sounds -- maybe it's the nature of the Part D business, but it sounds to me from the conversation that just occurred with regards to when capital would be released that you kind of will remain on the books -- on the hook until current liabilities run off. And then -- so in a sense, you're selling really the renewal rights. Is that an accurate way to think about it?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we really would be -- have responsibilities for the business up until the time of sale, unless there's some other arrangement with a buyer from that perspective. And of course, we really can't get into any detail of how that might work. But I think
componenttext: Well, we really would be -- have responsibilities for the business up until the time of sale, unless there's some other arrangement with a buyer from that perspective. And of course, we really can't get into any detail of how that might work. But I think the point was that, from an RBC perspective, the way that the RBC rules work, if we sold it now or part way through the year, you don't get 100% reduction of that at the end of 2016. Some of that bleeds over into 2017. And then, of course, we are settling up even in '17 just with respect to -- or potentially we could be settling up in '17 on just receiving payments, and again, just depending on how the sales process and what arrangements are worked out with the buyer.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Frank, I think you said that you thought the drag in 2016 from the reimbursement patterns on Part D would hurt by about $8 million, your excess investment income. Does that mean, looking at a 2017 model, just add that back?
componenttext: Okay. And then, Frank, I think you said that you thought the drag in 2016 from the reimbursement patterns on Part D would hurt by about $8 million, your excess investment income. Does that mean, looking at a 2017 model, just add that back?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. Let me modify that. In 2017, there's still going to be a -- here again, all that's kind of assuming that we have the business for the better part of 2016. And then there are -- you'd have a little bit of drag in 2017 just pending the receipt, if
componenttext: Correct. Let me modify that. In 2017, there's still going to be a -- here again, all that's kind of assuming that we have the business for the better part of 2016. And then there are -- you'd have a little bit of drag in 2017 just pending the receipt, if you will, of the various receivables that we would anticipate as of the end of '16.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, Steven Schwartz just kind of asked my question. But yes, I was just trying to understand what it is exactly you're selling. And I guess, is it the right way to think of it as mostly renewal rights deal? I mean, there is -- are there really s
componenttext: Yes. I guess, Steven Schwartz just kind of asked my question. But yes, I was just trying to understand what it is exactly you're selling. And I guess, is it the right way to think of it as mostly renewal rights deal? I mean, there is -- are there really standalone systems or other kind of distribution assets that would transfer with a business like that -- like this Part D business?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It really is a -- it's a sale of the contracts to be able to offer the Part D prescription drug coverage. So to a certain degree, it is the renewal rights, if you want to think about it that way. There aren't any hard assets. We don't have any system
componenttext: Yes. It really is a -- it's a sale of the contracts to be able to offer the Part D prescription drug coverage. So to a certain degree, it is the renewal rights, if you want to think about it that way. There aren't any hard assets. We don't have any systems, those type of things that are infrastructure, if you will, that's being sold.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just follow-up on an earlier question, too. I guess, the lack of earnings impact has to do with the fact that this is just a short-tail business, so it resolve -- it kind of resolves itself over the next 12 months and then someone woul
componenttext: All right. And then just follow-up on an earlier question, too. I guess, the lack of earnings impact has to do with the fact that this is just a short-tail business, so it resolve -- it kind of resolves itself over the next 12 months and then someone would have the right to kind of take the book from there if they wanted to.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on -- touching on, and I apologize if I missed this, but did you all go through kind of where you're getting new money yields right now on investment grade and below investment grade? And I'd also be interested if you're seeing kind of stres
componenttext: And then just on -- touching on, and I apologize if I missed this, but did you all go through kind of where you're getting new money yields right now on investment grade and below investment grade? And I'd also be interested if you're seeing kind of stress or need for derisking in any part of your investment portfolio outside of energy?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Randy, as far as where we're placing our money, I mentioned it's primarily the industrial sector, and that's where it's been, as well, we mentioned for the last 2 or 3 quarters. Within that, it's mostly been in the consumer sector. The transportatio
componenttext: Well, Randy, as far as where we're placing our money, I mentioned it's primarily the industrial sector, and that's where it's been, as well, we mentioned for the last 2 or 3 quarters. Within that, it's mostly been in the consumer sector. The transportation, some of the other industrial sectors, we haven't really added to our energy exposure. As far as derisking, we don't see, at this point, a need to sell any of our bonds. Again, let's talk about energy because that's what people -- mostly the concern is. We feel confident in the bonds that we have, and we expect that there'd be money good. So we don't expect to sell any of those. In the last few years, we have, I think, done a good job of spreading the risk of we were a little overweight on financials a few years ago. I think it's -- I think we're pleased with where we are with our distribution by sector.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the yields, did you touch on where you're getting new money yields in investment grade? And if it's -- is it investment grade kind of A-? Is that the center point of the portfolio right now?
componenttext: And just on the yields, did you touch on where you're getting new money yields in investment grade? And if it's -- is it investment grade kind of A-? Is that the center point of the portfolio right now?

componenttext: It's A-, BBB+.

componenttext: And what yield did you get in the fourth quarter there?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the fourth quarter, we were just a little under 5%, and I mentioned earlier that we had some tax derivative sales at the end of the year that actually pushed us a little bit under 5%. Had we not done that, I can't remember, but it seemed like we'd been
componenttext: On the fourth quarter, we were just a little under 5%, and I mentioned earlier that we had some tax derivative sales at the end of the year that actually pushed us a little bit under 5%. Had we not done that, I can't remember, but it seemed like we'd been 5%, 10%, or in that range. So far, this quarter, we invested a little over $100 million at 5.25%. But rates have, just in the last few weeks, have gone down. And so if we invested money today, it'd probably be around 5%.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to John Nadel with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And we'll go next to John Nadel with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. One on the American Income agent count. If I look 3Q to 4Q, I'm kind of surprised by the decline. Maybe it's nothing more than some calling of underperformers at your end. I suspect that's really the answer for Liberty, but c
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. One on the American Income agent count. If I look 3Q to 4Q, I'm kind of surprised by the decline. Maybe it's nothing more than some calling of underperformers at your end. I suspect that's really the answer for Liberty, but can you give us some color on that?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your question was American Income, or was it Liberty?
componenttext: I think your question was American Income, or was it Liberty?

componenttextpreview: Well, it's a question about American Income. I just -- I suspect because we typically see that kind of calling at Liberty in the fourth quarter. It doesn't -- I don't think we tend to see as much in American Income. But maybe I'm wrong.
componenttext: Well, it's a question about American Income. I just -- I suspect because we typically see that kind of calling at Liberty in the fourth quarter. It doesn't -- I don't think we tend to see as much in American Income. But maybe I'm wrong.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. There's 2 reasons for the lower guidance. It's based, in part, on the lower recruiting numbers I've seen during the fourth quarter of 2015 and January this year. Just remember, 2016 follows too strong years of agency and sales growth at A
componenttext: Okay, thank you. There's 2 reasons for the lower guidance. It's based, in part, on the lower recruiting numbers I've seen during the fourth quarter of 2015 and January this year. Just remember, 2016 follows too strong years of agency and sales growth at American Income. Over the 2-year period, our agency grew by 23%. So based on our historical data, I just would expect slower growth year in 2016. I'll be in a better position to give that guidance in the end of the second. Certainly, by the third quarter call, we'll have a better feel for the agent growth for 2016.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But the dip from the third quarter to the fourth quarter in the actual agent count, not producing, but -- I'm sorry, not the average producing agent count, but the actual year -- quarter end agent count. What was the driver of that?
componenttext: Okay. But the dip from the third quarter to the fourth quarter in the actual agent count, not producing, but -- I'm sorry, not the average producing agent count, but the actual year -- quarter end agent count. What was the driver of that?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you look back at that, that's seasonal, with the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. Within American income, there's always a seasonal drop from third to fourth quarter.
componenttext: And if you look back at that, that's seasonal, with the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. Within American income, there's always a seasonal drop from third to fourth quarter.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Then the second question is, that sensitivity that you provided on the $100 million roughly of downgrade is equating to roughly 2 points on risk-based capital. Is that a -- what is the downgrade there? Is it a 1-notch downgrade? Or is it an en
componenttext: Okay, okay. Then the second question is, that sensitivity that you provided on the $100 million roughly of downgrade is equating to roughly 2 points on risk-based capital. Is that a -- what is the downgrade there? Is it a 1-notch downgrade? Or is it an entire letter downgrade? Meaning, is that -- if we thought about $100 million of your BBBs going to BBs.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, I mean, that's, again, kind of a rule of thumb in looking at different multiple scenarios and kind of looking at just kind of what, I hate to use the word averages, but just kind of what can you glean from taking a look at all those multiple sc
componenttext: Generally, I mean, that's, again, kind of a rule of thumb in looking at different multiple scenarios and kind of looking at just kind of what, I hate to use the word averages, but just kind of what can you glean from taking a look at all those multiple scenarios, including taking a look at just some of the part -- just some of the -- we did look at just -- at the BBBs, all right, and maybe really more NAIC Class 2s, and moving them down into Class 3, and what if everybody goes down a notch. And I mean, those are included in those various scenarios we took a look at.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In that case, it would still stay within the NAIC 2 category, correct?
componenttext: In that case, it would still stay within the NAIC 2 category, correct?

componenttext: It would stay within the -- well, there would be some that would go from NAIC 2 to NAIC 3...

componenttextpreview: 2 to 3. Yes, yes. Okay, all right.
componenttext: 2 to 3. Yes, yes. Okay, all right.
